content.title: Lower Extremity Amputation
content.definition: Lower extremity amputation is the surgical removal of part or all of the limb, performed when tissue is non-viable or unsalvageable due to critical limb ischemia, infection, trauma, or malignancy, with level selection based on healing potential and functional outcome.

indications.critical_limb_ischemia: Non-reconstructable arterial disease with tissue loss

transmetatarsal.cons: Requires adequate plantar flap, risk of equinus

above_knee_amputation.indication: BKA not feasible (knee flexion contracture, insufficient tissue)

level_selection.clinical_assessment: Tissue viability, infection extent, joint function

principles.save_knee_if_possible: BKA has much better prosthetic outcomes than AKA
principles.control_infection: May require initial guillotine, later revision

surgical_principles.wound_closure: Tension-free, may leave open if infected

rehabilitation.preprosthetic: Wound healing, stump shaping, ROM exercises
rehabilitation.prosthetic_fitting: 2-6 weeks after healing (BKA), longer for AKA

learning_objectives: List indications for lower extremity amputation
Compare amputation levels and their functional implications
Describe factors determining amputation level selection
clinical_pearls: Preserve the knee whenever possible - BKA has much better prosthetic outcomes
TcPO2 >30-40 mmHg predicts adequate healing potential
Long posterior flap is preferred technique for BKA
Energy expenditure increases significantly with higher amputation levels
